interpretation_summary: The replication followed the pre-registered plan closely: the analyst loaded the provided 150-country dataset, rescaled the democracy index, constructed cases-per-million, and estimated an OLS model with HC3 robust standard errors controlling for temperature and trade-openness. The resulting democracy coefficient (+78.96; SE = 19.82; p ≈ 0.00007) is positive, highly significant, and only ~9% smaller than the original estimate (+86.76). Thus, the focal qualitative claim—that more democratic countries reported more COVID-19 cases per capita early in the pandemic—is supported. Minor deviations (smaller sample, two controls omitted) were anticipated in the preregistration and are unlikely to overturn the finding. Overall, the replication faithfully reproduced the analytical approach and yields substantively comparable results.

fidelity_assessment.method_alignment: Full alignment: The code implemented the exact OLS specification (cases_per_million ~ democracy + temperature + openness) with HC3 robust SE as described in the preregistration. Variable scaling (democracy/10) and list-wise deletion matched the plan. Output was saved to the declared CSV.

deviations.issue_description: Sample contains 150 countries versus 163 in the original study because the compiled replication dataset lacked some observations.
deviations.impact: Low: Coefficient remains positive and significant; magnitude difference <10%.

deviations.issue_description: Precipitation and population-density controls used in some original robustness checks not included.
deviations.impact: Low: These covariates were absent by design and the preregistration opted for the author’s preferred pared-down model; unlikely to bias democracy coefficient materially.

results_comparison.hypothesis_tested: Across countries, higher democracy scores (0–10) are associated with a greater number of confirmed COVID-19 cases per million people (as of 3 Apr 2020), controlling for temperature and trade openness.
results_comparison.original_results: Coefficient on Democracy Index = 86.76 (SE not reported in initial excerpt; p = 0.0001), positive and statistically significant.
results_comparison.replication_results: Coefficient on Democracy Index = 78.96 (SE = 19.82; 95% CI: 40.11–117.81; p < 0.001; N = 150). Direction positive and significant.
results_comparison.overall_answer: Yes – the replication meets the preregistered criteria (positive sign and p < 0.05) and yields a magnitude reasonably close to the original.

replication_report: Replication successful: Democracy index remains positively associated with COVID-19 cases per million (+79 cases per 1-point increase, p < 0.001), corroborating the original estimate (+87).

failure_handling.suggestions: To bolster robustness, supply the missing precipitation and population-density controls or replicate on the full 163-country sample if data become available.

notes: Magnitude attenuation could stem from different country coverage or the HC3 correction. Future work might test sensitivity to alternative time windows and reporting biases in autocratic regimes.
